items.text:
"The police... they were like
superheroes, they were like
Superman to us... we looked up
to them."

text: Craig A. Miller, aka KAM, is a California-based political emcee who gained popularity with hip hop fans and music critics during the 1990s and early 2000s.
In this interview, he talks about his first experiences with police as a 10-year-old child in Los Angeles... and the lasting impact they had on him.

slideContent.classNames: history-slide relative w-full h-full flex items-center justify-center

text: Toni McNeil is a Community Organizer in the City of Stockton. She has served as a Community Liaison during police officer trainings.
During one of these training sessions, while talking to officers, she shared a story about an encounter her 20-year-old son had with the police.
He called her late one night and informed her he had just been pulled over. Officers were giving him instructions, warning him to keep his hands on the wheel.
Panicked, Toni, still in her night gown, grabbed her keys, ran out the door, and began driving toward his location.
During the training session with officers, she explained to them how she felt when arrived at the scene and he was OK...

title.content: How safe is this type of dog? Use the slider to rate it, from safest (green) to most dangerous (red).

data.feedbackTitle: Click each person to hear their perspective. Select the ONE who you think is making the most sense.

feedbacks.text: If it were someone else, I might feel differently, but I know Andrew and he's a good cop. And his WIFE is African-American! Bottom line is, he had a feeling about this guy and he acted on it, and he was professional the entire time. I don't see a problem here.

Based on what he told his supervisor, I guess you argue that he "profiled" the guy. My advice to him next time is to just state the facts - the guy was using his cell phone while driving. Don't mention how the guy looked - that'll just get you into trouble.

Sometimes "matter out of place" is a valid reason for making a stop. On my beat, half the time when I stop someone based on a feeling, I find that the subject IS engaged in other illegal behavior - he's carrying drugs, he's in violation of his parole... The streets would be a lot less safe if we stopped acting on our gut.

OK, so the officer can claim he had "cause" to make a stop, but be honest, how many times do you stop someone because they glanced at a cell phone at a stop light? Listen to what he said about the subject: "He didn't seem like someone who'd be driving this kind of car." Clearly race was a factor.

saying: Yes, Sir. I was parked along the side of the road near the intersection of West Beverley and Beach St. and then a car pulled up to the stoplight across the street.
And it stood out because it was like a brand new yellow Lamborghini and you don't see that everyday.
The driver was looking down and it appeared he was checking his cell phone.
As he drove past me, I got a better look at him, and he definitely didn't look like someone who would be driving this kind of car.
Since I had cause based on him looking at the cell phone, I started following him. I noticed there was only a temporary dealer plate on the back... so I decided to make the stop to investigate.
I approached the car and introduced myself and explained why I stopped him...
And this guy was really rude to me, and he complained that I didn't have good cause to stop him, that he had just purchased the car, that he just hadn't gotten the plates yet.
So I was like, look, no need to get an attitude. I got his license and temporary registration, and everything checked out...
So I just gave him a warning for cell phone use and let him carry on.

title.content: How safe is this type of dog? Use the slider to rate it, from safest (green) to most dangerous (red).

saying.text: If it were someone else, I might feel differently, but I know Andrew and he's a good cop. And his WIFE is African-American! Bottom line is, he had a feeling about this guy and he acted on it, and he was professional the entire time. I don't see a problem here.

feedback.description: Being familiar with, or even a member of, a certain group of people does not mean that you cannot have bias towards them in certain situations.

title.content: Drag and drop the description below to the matching Tenet.

choices.label: Be respectful in your words, tone, and demeanor
Treat people equally and without bias
Do what is best for people and follow through on your commitments

title.content: Drag and drop the scenario image below to the matching Tenet.

choices.text: A Latino officer stops a white male for a minor traffic violation. The man has a "Build a Wall - Send them Home" bumper sticker on his car. The man is cooperative but a bit rude. The officer refers to him as "Sir" throughtout and lets him proceed with a warning.

Officers dealing with an agitated man who accidentally trespassed and is terrified of being arrested and doesn't want to come out. Officer reassures him that he just needs to answer the questions and follows through.
Officers pulls over a trans-gender person whose DL picture, name and listed gender don't match. He pulls them aside to talk to them privately out of earshot of others in the car.
During a field contact, a subject is trying to explain why he ran when the officer asked him to stop. The officer listens carefully.

data.title: Evalutate how the officer did for each tenet by dragging the sliders

instruction.content: What could the officer do to give her more of a voice?

items.text: Speak to her in a quiet and calm done of voice.
items.feedback: While your tone does matter, remember, "voice" is about giving the SUBJECT a voice - by respectfully listening to her.

items.text: Listen to her explanation about the face covering. Ask her if there is a way she would feel comfortable showing her face.
items.feedback: Yes. Give the person an opportunity to explain and ask questions, rather than just dismiss her concerns.

items.text: Give her more of an opportunity to justify why she was speeding.
items.feedback: She already explained that she didn't notice the posted signs. There was another, more important way the officer could have given her a voice.

instruction.content: What could the officer do to show her more respect?

items.text: Advocate for her to be proud of who she is and to reveal her face.
items.feedback: Definitely not. "voice" not about giving someone a compliment, especially when you're asking her to ignore her religious beliefs.

items.text: Acknowledge her discomfort and suggest an alternate way she could verify her identity
items.feedback: Good. Even just acknowledging that this was an uncomfortable request would have shown that the officer was being respectful of her religious customs.

items.text: To avoid offending her, don't worry about the ID verification in this case.
items.feedback: Showing respect is not about ignoring a legal requirement to avoid offending her. What else might you do?

feedback.title: Voice
feedback.text: When I tried to explain my reasons for not removing my veil, he was dismissive. He didn't take the time to listen to me.

feedback.title: Neutrality
feedback.text: Maybe he treats everyone this way, but he seemed particularly dismissive of me. But I wonder if he had been more respectful if I wasn't Muslim.

feedback.title: Respect
feedback.text: I guess he was polite, but I definitely did not feel respected. He didn't acknowledge my religious beliefs.

feedback.title: Trustworthiness
feedback.text: Once I showed him my face, he did what he said he would do, and he didn't give me a ticket. But he was disrespectful, and it's things like this that make me lose trust in ALL law enforcement.

And later that evening, over dinner,
the driver tells her husband about
what happened...
